direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. The area of a parallelogram formed by four linear equations can be found using determinants as follows: \[Area = |ab - ac|.\] For the first set of parallel sides, $|ad - ab|$ represents the absolute difference in areas when comparing side lengths along either pair of opposite sides ($ac$ versus $bd$). Thus, \(|ab - ad|\) equals half the original area because both expressions yield twice the length times width but one includes negative contributions due to reflection over y-axis; therefore it equates exactly halves our desired outputted 'area'. direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. The area of a parallelogram formed by four linear equations can be found using determinants as follows: \[Area = |ab - ac|.\] For the first set of parallel sides, $|ad - ab|$ represents the absolute difference in areas when comparing side lengths along either pair of opposite sides ($ac$ versus $bd$). Thus, \(|ab - ad|\) equals half the original area because both expressions yield twice the length times width but one includes negative contributions due to reflection over y-axis; therefore it equates exactly halves our desired outputted 'area'.
